patients.name: Maggie P.
patients.bio: Maggie is a retired physician navigating her husband’s APOE4/4 status and early-stage Alzheimer's treatment and arranging care. While their retirement home is close to a major hospital, they now live five hours from their closest relatives.

cards.quote: I'm trying not to panic, but I feel overwhelmed and lost. Our retirement plans are going to look very different from what we dreamed of.
cards.contextDescription: After the initial shock, Maggie is trying to find a way to cope with the diagnosis.
cards.goals: Improve husband’s quality of life by exploring treatments options while balancing risks and benefits
cards.strengths: A medical background, proximity to large hospitals, and financial stability
cards.anxieties: Lack of treatment options, limited support network, and treatment risks

cards.quote: For me, it's like living under a dark cloud. I’m trying to hang onto hope.
cards.contextDescription: After the initial shock, Maggie is trying to find a way to cope with the diagnosis.

cards.quote: We’re torn about starting lecanemab treatment. The statistics show high risks for little benefit, but he’s relatively young and fit. Even as an MD, I find the decision hard to make.
cards.contextDescription: Despite her medical background, Maggie found it difficult to make a decision about her husband's treatment. After much deliberation, they decided to start lecanemab.

cards.quote: We needed to pause treatment after four infusions. Thankfully, he’s not showing behavioral changes…still, it’s back to the drawing board.
cards.contextDescription: After an initially smooth start, Maggie and her husband were forced to stop lecanemab treatments, and are now considering clinical trial options.

patients.name: Nancy A.
patients.bio: Nancy, who lost her mother to Alzheimer's, leans on her research background to stay up-to-date with the latest research and is beginning to consider clinical trial options.

cards.quote: Learning that I was APOE4/4 rocked my world. I don’t think I was as prepared as I thought.
cards.contextDescription: Nancy's mother's Alzheimer's diagnosis made her more aware of her own risk, and motivated to take a genetic test.
cards.goals: Preserve quality of life, take preventative health actions, and actively pursue new treatment opportunities
cards.strengths: Research background, proactive attitude, and strong support system
cards.anxieties: Concerned about children's genetic risks, and limited treatment options

cards.quote: Learning that I was APOE4/4 rocked my world. I don’t think I was as prepared as I thought.
cards.contextDescription: Nancy believed she was mentally prepared for the results, but found herself struggling with the implications.

cards.quote: I have to think that this genetic marker is not my destiny. I’m trying to think of it as an opportunity.
cards.contextDescription: Though anxious about the implications of her APOE4/4 status, Nancy is determined to stay positive and proactive.

cards.quote: I'm lucky to have a science background. I've been following a few companies and their studies, and there really are more options than we would have had even a few years ago.
cards.contextDescription: Leaning on her research background, Nancy is diving deep into clinical data as she considers study options.

patients.name: Timothy K.
patients.bio: Timothy is APOE4/4 carrier who lost his mother to Alzheimer's. After learning of his genotype, he's beginning to take his first steps toward confronting his new reality.

cards.quote: I'm scared. And I know that I can't let my stress about this get me sick. But right now, I'm in a pretty bad mental place about it. This is all very new.
cards.contextDescription: Timothy expected to find out he was an APOE4 carrier, but the reality of the diagnosis hit him harder than he anticipated.
cards.goals: Manage emotional well-being whilst making proactive changes and finding HCPs who understand APOE4-specific needs
cards.strengths: Strong financial stability, high level of physical fitness, and high metabolic health
cards.anxieties: Anxiety about potential cognitive decline, inadequate medical support, and the emotional weight of witnessing mother's life with AD

cards.quote: After mom died of Alzheimer’s I used a 23andme DNA kit to see if I’m a APOE4 carrier. I thought it would be helpful to know.
cards.context: Motivated to take a genetic test
cards.contextDescription: Hoping that knowing his genetic status would help him prepare for the future, Timothy took a 23andMe test.

cards.quote: Knowing about my APOE4/4 status has had the opposite effect from what I’d hoped – I feel like I’ve lost all my interest in the things I used to enjoy.
cards.contextDescription: Timothy expected to find out he was an APOE4 carrier, but the reality of the diagnosis hit him harder than he anticipated.

cards.quote: Now it’s been over a year since I’ve learned that I’m APOE4/4, I finally feel like I’m ready to confront it with more than a healthy lifestyle.
cards.contextDescription: After a year of struggling with his diagnosis, Timothy is ready to take the next steps in his journey and is actively engaging in online and offline APOE4 communities.
